bolted_joints package¶

Submodules¶

bolted_joints.bolt module¶

Calculate the flexibility of a fastener in a lap joint.

class bolted_joints.bolt.Bolt(dia, bolt_type, e, c=1)¶

Bases: object

A class representing a single fastner.

dia(float)¶
Type:shank diameter
bolt_type(str)¶
Type:fastener type. Maybe either ‘rivet’ or ‘bolt’
e(float)¶
Type:Young’s modulus
c(float)¶
Type:flexibility
k(float)¶
Type:stiffness
boeing(t1, t2, e1, e2)¶

Calculate the flexibility using the Boeing method.

c

Return the fastener flexibility based on the chosen method.

flex_method¶

Return the fastener flexibility method.

grumman(t1, t2, e1, e2)¶

Calculate the flexibility using the Grumman method.

huth(t1, t2, e1, e2, mat1, mat2, lap_type='single')¶

Calculate the flexibility using the Huth/Airbus method.

k

Return the fastener stiffness based on the flexibility method.

swift(t1, t2, e1, e2)¶

Calculate the bolt stiffness using the Swift/Douglas method.

tate(t1, t2, e1, e2, nu_b)¶

Calculate the flexibility using the Tate and Rosenfeld method.

vought(t1, t2)¶

Calculate the flexibility using the Vought method.

Note: only applies for aluminum sheets joined by steel fasteners

bolted_joints.bolt_group module¶

Take user-supplied fastener information fastener information (i.e. location, diameter, etc.) and applied loads for a 3D fastener group and solve for the loads applied to each fastener.

Version:
Python 3.x
Required modules:
  • np
  • math
  • csv
Inputs:

On running the script, the user is requested to input the file path for input files conatining the the necessary fastener and loading information.

Fastener and applied loads information must be in a .CSV file. The fastener information .CSV must contain the following fields and headers:

ID (int): fastener ID (must be unique integers) x, y, z (float): X, Y, and Z coordinates for each fastener dia (float): fastener diameter E (float): Young’s Modulus G (float): shear modulus l (float): grip length

The applied loads .CSV must contain the following fields and headers (in order):

ID (int) - load ID (each ID must be unique) x, y, z (float): X, Y, and Z coordinates for each applied load fx, fy, fz (float): X, Y, and Z force components for each applied load mx, my, mz (float): X, Y, and Z moment components for each applied

load
Assumptions:
  • rigid body mechanics (see TODO)
  • unit system remains consistent (i.e. US or SI)
returns:
CSV containing all the force vectors for each

fastener
rtype:

fastener_loads.csv (file)

Todo

  • Script currently accepts fastener moduli, but conservatively assumes rigid body mechanics. Functionality needs to be added to calculate loads based on fastener stiffness
  • Add ‘Totals’ row to end of output file
  • report values smaller than 1e-9 as zeros
class bolted_joints.bolt_group.FastenerGroup(*fasteners)¶

Bases: object

A fastener group.

append(newFastener)¶

Add a newFastener to group.

cg¶

Find the center of gravity of the fastener group.

The x-component of the CG is calculated

X_bar = sum(weight * x_i) / sum(weight)

The weight factor ‘weight’ is typically a function of stiffness (i.e. area multiplied by modulus), but in this case it is a function of Fastener.wt.

clear()¶

Clear the FastenerGroup of all Fasteners.

getfromCSV(fastPath)¶

Import list of fasteners from CSV

moi¶

Return the second moment of inertia for the group about each axis.

Each value in the returned vector corresponds to the app.

writetoCSV(fileName)¶

Output resulting fastener loads to a CSV

bolted_joints.fastener module¶

A fastener class for bolted joint calculations.

class bolted_joints.fastener.Fastener(ID, xyz, diameter, E, G, length, wt=1, axis=[0, 0, 0])¶

Bases: object

Fastener class containing an ID, location in space, and load vector.

area¶

Cross-sectional area of the fastener.

compliance¶

Return the compliance of the fastener in each direction.

The compliance in each direction is the inverse of the stiffness.

stiffness¶

Return stiffness of the fastener in each direction.

The stiffness is calculated based on the diameter and material moduli of the fastener. The x-direction is the shaft axis.

Note: this does not account for total behavior of the joints.

bolted_joints.lap_joint module¶

Calculate the bearing load distribution on a lap joint

The lap joint is defined by a user-supplied *.csv file. The joint is assumed to belayed out like the diagram below.

Lap 2

2—–4—–6—–8—-> P2 | | | | B1 B2 B3 B4 | | | |

Pin <—-1—–3—–5—–7—-> P1
Lap 1

The bolts are shown as Bi, the nodes on the top lap are odd, and the nodes on the lower lap are even. The input load is Pin and the output loads are given by P1 for the bottom lap and P2 for the top lap.

Required modules:
  • math
  • csv
  • numpy
  • mechpy.bolt_flex

Inputs:

The *.csv should be organized by fastener
# TODO: cleanup table samples
fasteners
ID Thickness 1 Thickness 2 Modulus Pitch Diameter Bolt Type Nu 1 t11 t12 e1 pitch1 d1 type1 nu_b_1 2 t21 t22 e2 pitch2 d2 type2 nu_b_2 3 t31 t32 e3 pitch3 d3 type3 nu_b_3 4 t41 t42 e4 pitch4 d4 type4 nu_b_4
joint info
p_in input load p_out1 lap 1 output load p_out2 lap 2 output load width joint width e1 lap 1 modulus e2 lap 2 modulus mat1 lap 1 material type mat2 lap 2 material type nu1 lap 1 poisson’s ratio nu2 lap2 poisson’s ratio joint_type single or double shear
# TODO: add complete list of formulations
stiffness formulation
  • ‘Huth’
  • etc.
Assumptions:
  • For stepped joints, the step occurs halfway between the fasteners

class bolted_joints.loadset.LoadSet(*loads)¶

Bases: object

A set of loads.

clear()¶

Clear the load set of loads.

Import applied loads from a CSV.

insert(key, newLoad)¶

Insert new load at specified index.

sumLocation¶

Return __sumLocation attribute.

__sumLocation is kept private to ensure that, whenever it is changed, the set is updated and the total moment is accurate.

totalForce¶

Return __totalForce.

totalMoment¶

Return __totalMoment.
